newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Nagorno-Karabakh row almost wrecks Lisbon summit.
newsitem.headline: Nagorno-Karabakh row almost wrecks Lisbon summit.

text.p: Bitterness over a conflict in a remote corner of Europe almost wrecked the Lisbon security summit on Tuesday, forcing diplomats to revert to an unusual last-minute manoeuvre to avoid a major embarassment.
Disaster loomed as negotiations between Azerbaijan and Armenia over the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh hit a brick wall with no hint of a breakthrough in sight.

Forced into action by the threat of Azerbaijan vetoing the entire final summit declaration, international mediators agreed to drop all reference to the dispute from the closing document and issued a separate statement on it instead.

Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan sat stony-faced at the final session of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) meeting. Azeri President Heydar Aliyev, who dropped his veto threat, hailed his success.
"I am very satisfied," Aliyev told a news conference.
Ter-Petrosyan, by contrast, cancelled a planned news conference.
The conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed enclave with an Armenian majority which is surrounded by Azeri territory, flared in the Cold War era.
It is also a reminder of the instability and security problems that still haunt many parts of the former Soviet Union and could threaten European security.
About 10,000 people were killed in fighting which flared in Nagorno-Karabakh in 1988. The clashes ended under a ceasefire signed in 1994 but up to one million refugees still live in tent camps.

Azerbaijan wanted its territorial integrity reaffirmed in the final summit statement. It also sought support for demands to define Nagorno-Karabakh's legal status clearly, based on the right to self-determination, and guarantees over its security.
Armenia blocked Azerbaijan's demands, earning the wrath of other states at the closing session, including Russia.
"I regret that one delegation could not accept this. These principles have the support of all other participating states," said Swiss Foreign Minister Flavio Cotti, chairman in office of the OSCE.
Azerbaijan's demands were included in the separate statement drawn up to the indignation of Ter-Petrosyan.

He rejected Cotti's remarks, saying they did not correspond with the views of a group of 11 countries in the so-called Minsk Group set up to mediate over Nagorno-Karabakh. He has said "unilateral solutions" must not be imposed over the enclave.
"I would like to express concern in connection with this statement. In our view it does not reflect the spirit and the letter of the Minsk Group," Ter-Petrosyan said.
His comments made clear the leaders left Lisbon as far apart on Nagorno-Karabakh as when they arrived.

The OSCE agreed at its last summit, in Budapest in 1994, to prepare a multinational peacekeeping force for Nagorno-Karabakh but deployment cannot go ahead until the two sides agree full terms for peace.
"You all know that no progress has been achieved in the last two years to resolve the Nagorno-Karabkah conflict," Cotti said.
Matters have been further complicated by tension over an election in Nagorno-Karabakh last month which Armenia acclaimed and Azerbaijan condemned.
